skill.name: pptx-posters
skill.description: Create research posters using HTML/CSS that can be exported to PDF or PPTX. Use this skill ONLY when the user explicitly requests PowerPoint/PPTX poster format. For standard research posters, use latex-posters instead. This skill provides modern web-based poster design with responsive layouts and easy visual integration.

security_audit.summary: The 433 static findings are overwhelmingly false positives. The skill is a documentation-heavy tool for creating research posters. The 'external_commands' detections are legitimate documentation examples showing command-line workflows (creating directories, running Chrome headless, using LibreOffice). The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' findings are pattern-based false positives triggered by words like 'md5sum' and 'sha' in PDF quality checking documentation. The 'system reconnaissance' findings are standard PDF analysis commands (pdfinfo, pdffonts, pdfimages) used for poster quality validation. The 'certificate/key files' detection is triggered by CSS linear-gradient syntax patterns. No actual dangerous code execution, credential access, or malicious patterns exist.

content.user_title: Create HTML Research Posters with PPTX Export
content.value_statement: Transform research content into professional research posters using HTML and CSS with AI-generated visuals. Export to PDF for printing or convert to PowerPoint for conference presentations.
actual_capabilities: Generate HTML/CSS research posters with fixed 36x48 inch poster dimensions
Create AI-powered visual elements with poster-specific formatting requirements
Export posters to PDF via browser print functionality
Convert PDF posters to PowerPoint format using LibreOffice
Apply scientific poster design principles and typography hierarchy
Integrate with scientific-schematics skill for diagram generation
limitations: Only use when user explicitly requests PPTX/PowerPoint format
Requires external tools (Chrome/Firefox) for PDF export
Limited to 5-6 content sections to prevent overflow
AI-generated visuals must follow strict poster readability guidelines

prompt_templates.title: Basic poster creation
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants a simple research poster
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an HTML research poster about [TOPIC] with title, authors, introduction, methods, results, and conclusions sections. Generate AI visuals for each section first.

prompt_templates.title: Conference-specific poster
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs poster for specific conference
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 36x48 inch HTML poster for [CONFERENCE_NAME] about [RESEARCH_TOPIC]. Follow the conference guidelines and include university logo space.

prompt_templates.title: Data-heavy poster
prompt_templates.scenario: User has complex data to visualize
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an HTML poster showcasing [DATA_TYPE] results. Create simple bar charts and diagrams with maximum 3-4 elements per visual, giant text labels.

prompt_templates.title: PPTX export required
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an HTML poster then export to PDF and convert to PPTX. Use the python-pptx method for direct PowerPoint creation with all visuals embedded.

output: Generated 5 AI visuals: hero banner, workflow diagram, methods schematic, results chart, conclusions summary
Created HTML poster with 36x48 inch dimensions and three-column layout
Applied scientific typography hierarchy (108pt title, 52pt headers, 34pt body)
Exported to PDF with proper margins and background graphics enabled

output_examples.input: Design a conference poster for neuroscience research
output: Created poster with university branding and proper section formatting
Generated simplified neural pathway diagrams with poster-readable text
Applied color scheme matching conference guidelines
Exported to PDF and converted to PowerPoint for editing

best_practices: Generate ALL visuals before creating HTML - target 60-70% visual content
Use poster format specifications in EVERY AI visual prompt (giant text, 50% whitespace)
Preview at 25% zoom to ensure readability from 6 feet away
Limit to 300-800 words total text across all sections
anti_patterns: Creating complex 7+ stage workflows - simplify to 3-4 mega-steps maximum
Using small text in generated visuals - always specify 80pt+ font sizes
Adding too many sections - maximum 5-6 sections to prevent overflow
Skipping visual generation - always create AI visuals before HTML assembly

faq.question: When should I use this skill instead of latex-posters?
faq.answer: Only use pptx-posters when user explicitly requests PowerPoint/PPTX format. For all other poster requests, use latex-posters as the default.

faq.question: Why are my generated visuals unreadable?
faq.answer: You forgot poster format requirements. Always include POSTER FORMAT with specifications for giant text (80pt+), 50% whitespace, and maximum 3-4 elements.

faq.question: How do I export to PowerPoint?
faq.answer: First export HTML to PDF via browser print, then convert using LibreOffice: libreoffice --headless --convert-to pptx poster.pdf

faq.question: What if content is cut off at edges?
faq.answer: You have too much content. Reduce to maximum 5 sections and 800 words total. Check browser preview before exporting.

faq.question: Can I edit the poster after creation?
faq.answer: Yes, edit the HTML file directly for quick changes. For major changes, regenerate visuals first then update HTML.

faq.question: What image resolution should I use?
faq.answer: Generate visuals at 300+ DPI for print quality. The HTML template scales images appropriately for the 36x48 inch format.
